post_text:
A very meaningful message we received last night from a parent, following our Zoom classroom open house (shared with permission):

I just logged off the open house event and am so, so impressed with the daily/weekly schedule. It manages to foster consistency AND flexibility AND agency AND interaction AND independence. It also makes sense, and the supporting materials are extremely helpful. It feels like TPS, which is the highest compliment I can give.

I deeply appreciated that not once in the meeting did any TPS staff member frame any of the plans, or the upcoming school year, through a deficit/problematized lens. Framing learning of any kind as less-than, a problem, a loss, etc can't be any kind of way to engage students' best efforts. Not to diminish the reality of the struggles and ALL of the extra planning and services this requires - but no kid ever wanted to be a part of a problem. Thank you all for making sure they stay positive and equally engaged.

You all should be as proud as you are tired.

New Hope for Families
February 7 at 5:57 PM ·

We were pleased to accept a recent donation of 30 educational play kits made by students at The Project School / Bloomington Project School for the children we serve. Each kit contains developmental learning toys appropriate for toddlers through preschoolers. Peri, one of the students in "Ms. Liz" Stelle's kindergarten class at The Project School, helped deliver the play kits to children in our daycare program. Thank you, TPS!

We don't want anyone to miss out on the opportunity to explore TPS, especially as there will be new spaces opening up this year due to our exciting expansion!
